quote: Okay, let's stand up and be counted: who has been writing diamond graph code? Mine's 60 lines.
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: in a discussion about the patent for diamond graphs

quote: Bug, undocumented behaviour, feature? I dont know. It all seems to work in 1.6.0, so everyone should downgrade now... :)
author: Barry Rowlingson

quote: Robert, I really like you, but you're one of the strangest persons I know.
author: Kurt Hornik
context: in a discussion with Robert Gentleman

quote: I'm always thrilled when people discover what lexical scoping really means.
author: Robert Gentleman

quote: My institution has a particularly diabolical policy on intellectual property, especially on software.
author: Ross Ihaka

quote: If you imagine that this pen is Trellis, then Lattice is not this pen.
author: Paul Murrell
context: on the difference of Lattice (which eventually was called grid) and Trellis

quote: It is good to look around at what is available, but one shouldn't miss what is under one's nose either.
author: Robert Gentleman

quote: What we have is nice, but we need something very different.
author: Robert Gentleman

quote: Readable, obvious, maintainable, 'portable' for some value of 'portable'...
author: Barry Rowlingson

quote: `They' did write documentation that told you that Perl was needed, but `they' can't read it for you.
author: Brian D. Ripley

quote: Overall, SAS is about 11 years behind R and S-Plus in statistical capabilities (last year it was about 10 years behind) in my estimation.
author: Frank Harrell (SAS User, 1969-1991)

quote: I want a budget.
author: Peter Dalgaard
context: in a talk about Tcl/Tk, meaning to say `I want a button widget'

quote: You can be maximally lazy, but still be efficient.
author: Kevin Murphy
context: describing the implementation of an algorithm

quote: Andrew Thomas: ...and if something goes wrong here it is probably not WinBUGS since that has been running for more than 10 years...<x>Peter Green (from the back): ... and it still hasn't converged!
author: Andrew Thomas and Peter Green

quote: This is all documented in TFM. Those who WTFM don't want to have to WTFM again on the mailing list. RTFM.
author: Barry Rowlingson

quote: It really is hard to anticipate just how silly users can be.
author: Brian D. Ripley

quote: So apparently you wish to report as a bug the fact that R 1.8.0 is different from R 1.4.0.
author: Douglas Bates

quote: I plan to fix this - the report is just in case I forget or get hit by a bus.
author: Ross Ihaka

quote: Thomas W. Blackwell: I just discovered to my surprise that I cannot define a function with an argument named 'break' or 'while'!<x>Brian D. Ripley: No, they are reserved names. [...] Most progamming languages have reserved words, so I am surprised you are surprised.
author: Thomas W. Blackwell and Brian D. Ripley

quote: R has changed quite a lot recently, and older preconceptions do need to be checked against current information.
author: Brian D. Ripley

quote: But a difference of a few minutes means that this is well under 20% of the total time unless your statistical analysis is very much speedier than mine.
author: Brian D. Ripley

quote: I seem to recall that we were targetting 512k Macintoshes. In our dreams we might have seen 16Mb Sun.
author: Ross Ihaka
context: in reply to the question whether R&R thought when they started out that they would see R using 16G memory on a dual Opteron computer

quote: I quit using SAS in 1991 because my productivity jumped at least 20% within one month of using S-Plus.
author: Frank Harrell

quote: When a Certain Guru strips off people (God knows he's done it to me often enough) on this list, there's a damned good reason for it.
author: Rolf Turner
context: in a discussion about whether a friendly mailing list with more `customer service' attitude than R-help was needed

quote: Ah, so that's why my report of a bug in the RCheapViagra package didn't get through....
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: after Peter Dalgaard announced a new spam filter for R-bugs

quote: Henrik Bengtsson: Is there a way to turn off the (annoying) beep that occurs when one calls the locator() command and clicks the mouse? [...]<x>Brian D. Ripley: It's a feature of the windows() device. Windows is fond of beeping, and I just mute the sound.
author: Henrik Bengtsson and Brian D. Ripley

quote: Brian D. Ripley: Add to package utils in R-devel, after correction.  I was surprised you had fallen into the 1:0 trap.<x>Pat Burns: I'm surprised too -- good catch.
author: Brian D. Ripley adding Pat Burns' head() to the utils package

quote: As to whether you can do a Lilliefors test for several groups, that depends entirely on your ability to understand what the underlying question would be (see Adams D 1979).
author: Knut M. Wittkowski

quote: Jim Gustafsson: I would like to put my SAS-code into R. Could I do that, if yes, how?<x>Frank Harrell: Just reverse the procedure you use when you put R code into SAS. ;)
author: Jim Gustafsson and Frank Harrell

quote: Is this English or American (you know, the language referred to in the USA as `English')? [...] As an English English speaker, my sense and my employer's dictionary both suggest doubling here.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: in a discussion whether it is `subsetable' or `subsettable'

quote: As Brian says, there's nothing in the design that lets you do this, but then since you have the source there's nothing on the planet to stop you doing this. The design is not a law :)
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: answering the question whether the mouse position can be determined without any click

quote: Barry Rowlingson: Your grid above has 8*6 = 42 points.<x>(That was a subtle Hitchhikers Guide To The Galaxy reference there, honest, and not a stupid dumb multiplication mistake on my part after working four 18-hour days on the trot...)<x>Peter Dalgaard: [...] Don't panic, just throw yourself at the ground and miss.
author: Barry Rowlingson and Peter Dalgaard

quote: I have mentioned several times on this list that I'm in the process of developing a new and wonderful implementation of lme and I would prefer to continue working on that rather than modifying old-style code.
author: Douglas Bates

quote: Ivo Welch: Thanks. I will put in a suggestion that the docs refer to q() in `see also' for `stop'.<x>Brian D. Ripley: I don't think anyone else is confusing `exit' with `stop', though. I hope you don't when driving ....
author: Ivo Welch and Brian D. Ripley

quote: Before we get too carried away with this thread could you all please consider how the sd function calculates its result? [...] I'll tell you, it takes the square root of the variance.  How is the variance calculated for a numeric vector? First you calculate the mean *using floating point arithmetic* in which it is not necessarily true that N * k / N == k [...] Most of those tests [for numerical accuracy] end in a check using the all.equal function which checks if the relative difference is less than a threshold. That's about the best that you can do with floating point arithmetic.<x>Here endeth the sermon.
author: Douglas Bates
context: after a discussion why sd(rep(0.001, 15)) is not necessarily exactly 0

quote: The keboard is the standard Italian layout, which is missing the ~ (tilde) key. [...] Can anyone advice how to produce the ~ symbol, short of a copy/paste from MS Word?
author: Federico Calboli

quote: I'd like to prefix all these solutions with `Here's how to do it, but don't actually do it you crazy fool'. It's on a par with redefining pi, or redefining '+'. And then redefining '<-'. These techniques have their proper place, and that would be in the currently non-existent obfuscated R contest.<x>No, the R-ish (iRish?) way is to index vectors from 1. That's what the R gods intended!
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: in a discussion how vectors in R could be indexed starting from 0

quote: I think that it's generally a good idea not to resist the most natural way of programming in R.
author: John Fox
